qas.question: What other system of calculations are inherent in the Gregorian calendar?
Why is calculating the days of the Gregorian calendar not simple?
After each country adopted the calendar how did the weekly cycle continue?
What was the date of adoption for the calendar?
What was the previous day's date by the Julian calendar?

plausible_answers.text: Calculating the day of the week

qas.question: What is simple to do using the Gregorian system?

plausible_answers.text: the irregularities in the Gregorian system

qas.question: What makes Calgary the days of the week symbol in the Gregorian system?
What was interrupted when the Gregorian calendar was adopted in each country?

context: In conjunction with the system of months there is a <a0_0>system of weeks<a0_0/>. A physical or electronic calendar provides conversion from a given date to the weekday, and shows multiple dates for a given weekday and month. <b5_0>Calculating the day of the week<b5_0/> is not very simple, because of <b6_0>the <a1_0>irregularities<a1_0/> in the <b8_0>Gregorian system<b8_0/><b6_0/>. When the Gregorian calendar was adopted by each country, <b7_0>the weekly cycle continued<b7_0/> <a2_0>uninterrupted<a2_0/>. For example, in the case of the few countries that adopted the reformed calendar on the date proposed by Gregory XIII for the calendar's adoption, <a3_0>Friday, 15 October 1582<a3_0/>, the preceding date was <a4_0>Thursday, 4 October 1582<a4_0/> (Julian calendar).
